--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Mitchell Timin <zenguyuno@y...> wrote:

> My approach to evolution is very draconian; if a game
> playing ANN wants to make an invalid or illegal move I
> give it a very low fitness, and end the game right
> there.  That ANN will soon be eliminated from the
> population.  Usually, in the beginning, that happens
> to most of the ANNs, but hopefully not all of them.
> 

But learning what is legal and what it illegal can put
an extra strain on the already difficult problem.  For example,
a network that is doing quite well at the game yet occasionally
making illegal moves would be killed off, even if it is the
only network with such a high level ogf skill.  

Usually when I deal with this type of thing I just make
it so that no output can be illegal.  For example,
in Go I consider an illegal move attempt by the network
to be a requested pass.  That way a network that is otherwise
good can still get its due credit, and might even learn
to utilize its "criminal tendencies" to make rational decisions.
For example, although the Go network does have a pass output,
it may find it easier to instead pass by trying to place a piece
on an already-occupied square.  Who is to say this is a bad
way to communicate a pass if it gets the job done?  The point is to
give the network as many opportunities to communicate valid moves
as possible.
